-k que go (obsolete, no longer productive) A suffix found in words of Middle English, Old English, usually with an intensive or frequentative effect.

    tale, talk; steal, stalk; smile, smirk; mire, mirk; hear, hark; fare, firk; yare, yark

Basque
Suffix -k Ergative indefinite suffix.
Alternative forms -ek (after consonants)
≠ adverbial suffixes -ki and -ka.[1]

Uralic
-k (genitive -ku, partitive -kut) -kko -kki -uk
Derives nouns from verbs, or sometimes from other nominals. The derivations can express the following:
minema (“to go”) → minek (“a going”)
sõitma (“to drive”) → sõiduk (“vehicle”)
hõljuma (“to hover”) → hõljuk (“hovercraft”)
tõstma (“to raise”) → tõstuk (“lift”)
saama (“to receive”) → saak (“yield”)

Hungarian
Suffix -k ( plural suffix) -s, -es
nő (“woman”) →‎ nők (“women”)
hajó (“ship”) → hajók (“ships”)

Slavic
kъ(n) ke, ku | to, towards | √con com

k-

ka = 𒅗 ká (ka₂) = 𒆍 kà (ka₃) = 𒂵 ka₄ = 𒋡 ka₅ = 𒈜 ka₆ = 𒋝𒋙𒁷, 𒉾 ka₇ = 𒁽 ka₈ = 𒁉 ka₉ = 𒋃 ka₁₀ = 𒈜𒀀 ka₁₁ = 𒋼𒀀 ka₁₃ = 𒄰, 𒄰 ka₁₄ = 𒍪 ka₁₅ = 𒆕 ka₁₆ = 𒃶 ke = 𒆠

ké (ke₂) = 𒄀 kè (ke₃) = 𒀝 ke = 𒆤 ki = 𒆠

kí (ki₂) = 𒄀 kì (ki₃) = 𒀝 ki₄ = 𒆤 ki₆ = 𒍪 ki₇ = 𒆕 ki₈ = 𒄄 ku = 𒆪

kú (ku₂) = 𒅥 kù (ku₃) = 𒆬 ku₄ = 𒆭 ku₅ = 𒋻 ku₆ = 𒄩 ku₇ = 𒆯 ku₈ = 𒄖 ku₉ = 𒆰 ku₁₀ = 𒈪 ku₁₁ = 𒆠 ku₁₃ = 𒄣 ku₁₄ = 𒆲 ku₁₅ = 𒄞 ku₁₆ = 𒉈 ku₁₇ = 𒄫 ak = 𒀝
